Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Yummmm

xo9ILCvS95gfRMgtPjuRFA.text: Very rude, especially the hostess! Would not seat us even after we called ahead to say one out of four of our party was running late. The manager said no problem. However, hostess would not seat the 3 of us and gave away our table. Went next door to Grassroots and had a delicious meal. No restaurant, no matter how famous, should treat customers with such an attitude. We won't be back.

fyF6f-H7td6xYAMIw8u01A.text: In a city that loves its strip malls and chain restaurants, Pizzeria Bianco is an oasis in the desert.  Amongst the shimmery mirage of Cheesecake Factories, Sweet Tomatoes', and Papa Johns', Mr. Bianco has managed to thrive, opening not only a second restaurant, but a third shop specializing in sandwiches made with house baked bread.  Before I get too sentimental, there were flaws in my experience. As others have mentioned, the service is a bit brusque.  And unless you like wincefully salty and overly greasy things, you'll want to avoid the spiedini ($10) which is the sad marriage of two prosciutto wrapped logs of cheese.  On the other hand, the margherita ($13) pizza was a thing of beauty.  The creamy mozzarella was still bubbling when it hit my table and I could smell the fragrant basil before the pizza even arrived.  The sauce tasted as it should - fresh and bright with the deeply savory thrum of good quality tomatoes nudged just so with herbs and salt.  Above all, the crust was flawless - structurally sound enough to eat a slice without fork and knife, yet light and pliant.  There was the familiar calico pattern of an expertly fired char, and the crackly crisp yet wholesome corcione (the fancy pants Italian term for the crust) was one of the best executed I've seen outside New York City and Naples.  I regret that chain restaurants seem to be the new way of American eating.  But that lowering of expectations makes it even more exciting to find a restaurant that doesn't take short cuts, keeps the bar high, strives for perfecting the craft, keeps it real and is thus-ly rewarded.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States

Yyidr02ScdC3st6qdllNcA.text: Manager is clueless, restaurant is less then half full and he would not seat us because our entire party was no there yet. So we went next door to Grassroots where they will seat you, offer you a drink, let you order an app and great you with a smile. 3.5 stars is too generous for Bianco. Pizza, costumer service is non existent!!   BTW, if you are really looking for good pizza,  the Best pizza in town is at Joe's NY Pizza 7321 E Shoeman Ln, Scottsdale, AZ 85251!

Myk1O-R1sCQ2DEwIOyEnaw.text: Bianco used to own the market on artisan pizza in Phoenix, and in some opinions, all of the USA. In the past few years a number of artisan pizza spots have opened which are bringing Pizzeria Bianco some competition. Still, few compare to what Pizzera Bianco keeps delivering to the table time and time again.   I've been told by more than one person the pizzas here are "Amazing", "spectacular", "the best anywhere", and so on. While I did enjoy the thin crust and the fresh, flavorful toppings and ingredients, I was not completely blown away by the pizza here. I think the trouble is that there is *s*o*  *m*u*c*h* hype around these pizzas, it's impossible to go into this expecting anything other than "the absolute, hands down, best meal you've ever eaten". When you get to the other side of your dining experience, you find the meal just didn't quite live up to your expectations.  With that said, there's only one spot in Phoenix I like better than Bianco, and that's Federal. I'm not going to tell you it's the most amazing meal you'll ever eat, but in the world of artisan pizza, it's seriously hard to beat. I'd implore you to try Bianco for yourself, go in with appropriate expectations of a "really good pizza" and you won't be underwhelmed like I was.   If you feel like taking this Yelper's advice, stop in here for a pizza, go out and try the rest, then create your own informed, flavor filled opinion.  Happy Yelping Phoenix! Go eat pizza :-)

XUw2VDKC19D6zzr49It3VQ.text: This is an okay place. Nothing extraordinary about it at all... I honestly don't understand how this place got so famous.... go down to Gilbert and try Casanova brothers instead.

e5ydEOOIaAx0iX8wPV-9TQ.text: Pizzeria bianco is a very nice and fancy place. I went there with a bunch of friends and we tried many items on their menu. My personal favorite was the red marinara pasta. The pizzas were good but not so special in my opinion. Their mozzarella and tomato appetizer was good. I think this place might be a bit overrated.

DD5k2M4hBhMbwH0QLXL2pw.text: Cool.  Just saw that PB was nominated for a James Beard Award.  Checked into the Hotel and asked about the place.  Concierge told me that Jerry Seinfeld had chartered a plane to bring his group there from LA for Pizza.  Walked from the Biltmore against advice from the Desk that said it was too far--about a 30 min walk. Naturally, with all this buzz, the pizza is fantastic. Where on earth is the best pizza is a slipery slope and i am not getting on it.  The whole thing is, however, very cool.  They have a person in the window smashing tomatos into sauce.  I was involved in an urban gardening project in downtown Phoenix and they were growing ancient heritage Sonoran wheat ( the oldest grain in the hemisphere) to be used at PB. Well worth it to go.  BTW, i was there about 2pm on a Monday and the place was empty.

5oAP3Lz_LehZrLRmbEvcwA.text: My wife and son had dinner here last night.  Dinner was good.  Tomatoes were to die for with Burrata.  Pasta was good/ok pizza good/ok crust did not have the crispyness it use to.  We ate outside under security lights    They were very bright and  very white.    Made food look weird and made me feel like I was under interrogation.  Bianco is one of the treasures of Arizona. I have waited hours to eat here and at the down town location.  This place was empty.   Please give it a tune up and bring back the magic to what was a very special place

JDv4cvfNd8uf7ASIrvs__w.text: This was our First time we tried Bianco Pizza , we heard so many good comments about how great the pizza is!   The ingredients were fresh but I guess my expectations were so high and they undelivered. 1 salad , 2 drinks 2 pizza all for $77.00 plus tax and tip totaled $96.00...   Oh well Cibo pizza knocks it out of the park compared to this resturant. $15 personal pizza is not worth the money, service was average same as the food and drinks..   My Moscow mule was served in a glass - sorry but mules should be served in a cooper mug - get a clue .. Drink was weak and not very good.  The way to sum it up is average restaurant and not worth the wait , money or time!! Sorry just being honest ..  Ciao

kC5Q2a-VqtUPqpuDNFUEKw.text: Good ambience, good taste, lots of vegetarian options. They have a good collection of drinks. Tried all vegetarian pizzas. Margarita pizza was really good. Rosa pizza was something new but little salty.

CwFw6eDEb0E_qIXq4dAPtw.text: This is pizza made with top-quality ingredients and consumed within a very nice building in a very nice shopping center in a very nice area, so expect to pay for the privilege.  I'm rating it  based on the quality of the pizza ingredients and the bread with dipping oil, and the lack of anything tacky in the surroundings.  Also, the waiter was completely unobjectionable.  I thought my chair was a little too heavy and awkward; try sitting against the wall instead of out in the middle to avoid this problem.  If you like to fill up when you eat, you will need to order more than just a pizza; maybe get dessert, because these pizzas are on the small side.  If you want something very basic to eat, you will surely walk away hungry.  If this place sold hot chocolate, you wouldn't find regular hot cocoa; you would have to choose from three premium flavors, and if you couldn't face imported amaretto, organic hazelnut or mint grown on Mt. Everest, you'd be straight out of luck.  All the pizzas have such fancy toppings that I doubt most children would be interested in it.  I was there for a business lunch, and I am satisfied that my companion went away with a positive impression that Phoenix has high-quality, specialty pizzas.

0twYuWQi3ygC3ziBRAn-gQ.text: Had a work event here.  The wiseguy and sonny boy were the best.  The tres leches?  Was delicious.  The service was good as we had a large group.  The mixed drinks were spot.  Good atmosphere as well.  My only knock was the pasta was just "ok".  The papparedelle was the best of the bunch.

_gUIgxCQqBHJ3nl8fKUdgQ.text: Super high quality ingredients make every dish fresh and flavorful! Had an awesome salad and the pappardelle bolognese was super! Pizza was good as long you like this type of pizza.  Great casual service! Will return for sure

YgVT6nahmA-lr3YIF7EsvQ.text: This is our favorite restaurant to go to for lunch on the weekend. We have never been disappointed with the food or service. It is worth getting dessert and a cappuccino after your pizza!

pR2p33IcbWV9Q8Hvaxy_FA.text: This place is in line with all the other Bianco joints: legit.  Besides having arguably the best pizza in a 600 mile radius, the best fresh mozzarella in the valley, ultra fresh ingredients, and hop knot on tap, you can essentially walk into this place and get seated immediately any night.  I have never waited.  The service is always good at this location in my experience.  One thing about the pizza here.  It's an exercise in control and attention to detail.  The crust is always prefect, with some nice blistering and char. The mozzarella is lush and fresh.  The tomato sauce is simple and perfect.  By dialing in all the finest details, this place pumps out world class pies... I literally feeling like hugging the dude running oven duty every time I take my first bite.  This is my go to Bianco location.

UvRHK_xuK3X8G32BkC7K6g.text: We went to the 20th Street location where you're less likely to have to wait.  The restaurant's decorations are charming, eclectic, and the outside seating area quite nice given it's basically in a retail alley.  My husband and I shared a white pizza with pistachios & onions that was served hot, crusty & was delicious.  (They bring fresh bread and olive oil to the table while you're waiting on the order).  For a custom-made pizza, I had asked for mushrooms on my half of the pizza, the service was pretty darn fast.  My only suggestion would be to add a few more inventive side salads to the menu, but overall highly recommended.

GD45jku3tkK_McqesZ9HyQ.text: One time I waited over 3 hours to eat at the Pizzeria Bianco downtown....well, thank god those days are over. This new location is nice because there isn't usually a wait and they have the same menu as the other location....plus it's right by my yoga studio (cuz after yoga, I need some pizza...duh!). I went with my mom and we shared their super simple salad, which was good, but plain with just a light vinaigrette, and we had a half bianco verde half rosa pizza. The pizza was soooo good. Better than I remember from the other location (the lack of the wait time may have helped too). I like that these pizzas are very different than others in Phoenix....local pistachios on a pizza? Come on! Is it the best pizza in town? No...but it's definitely worth a try!  PS this may sound really dumb, but I had some leftovers and later that night I popped them in the micro in the plastic container and the container melted to the pizza...I was pretty devastated, so don't be dumb like me....safety first, use a plate :-P

dr8oxSDzQxfMLvZYdtqlYw.text: Although there is a ton of hype around this pizza and that can lead to disappointments this pizza did not fail. Great  taste and texture.  Wait staff was awesome.   Got to try that pie

R5YNyXvInmo5Blr8h-vu5w.text: LOVE this place!  The atmosphere is amazing, and the pizza is incredible.  What else is there to say??

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States

dwbx9fECx2nt3s6KGCRXnw.text: Had a late dinner here with a couple of friends.  Our server greeted us, explained about the menu and suggested that for the 3 of us, if we want pizza, we should order 2 or 3.  What the...??   1 would be suffice, especially if we would like to have a variety of dishes to share.  We ended up with their Market Salad, which was delicious.  Not dressed heavily, and was very refreshing.  We also ordered the Pappardelle with grass fed beef bolognese.  It was tasty but the pasta was cooked beyond al dente, which made the dish taste like something I can get from a Maggiano's.  Since Pizza Bianco is known for their pizzas, we just had to sample one and went with the Rosa, which is vegetarian, and added a roasted mushrooms.  We were served the pizza, and the server then said that the side of mushrooms will be ready in a minute or so.  Whoops.  Guess one has to be clearer when ordering and indicate the addition of mushrooms is for the pizza.  She apologized and replaced the pizza with one would include the mushrooms.   The pizza we got then had the mushrooms, but the underside of the pizza was almost completely charred/burnt.  We inquired and were able to send it back.  They fired up one more pizza, and this time it was done well.  The combination of the ingredients of the Rosa was very tasty.    Appreciated the staff wanting to make sure that we enjoyed all of food.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States

Cs8lNSTvtaXo0bqdvrdRuQ.text: Even though this isn't the original location it's even better because there's more room and better parking. I think less people know about this location and it's not as full. I think the pizzas are delicious and I've sampled a few things from the menu that my guests have tried as well. I do think that Cibo is a 5/5 and way better, but Bianco is still delicious. Try it out! (But try Cibo too)

y4fRwusBuy5SinhAVk0etw.text: Thin gourmet pizza with limited topping selection in a classy but unpretentious setting. Decor is thoughtful and unique, with lots of pictures on the walls. Pizza was a bit soggy and the oversized toppings tended to fall off. Prices seemed about 25% higher than they should be. All in all a nice spot, but not the pizza nirvana some would have you believe.
