ySx5zYdCtIwkEsyarxwHVg.text: Excellent quality ingredients made in a beautiful display. The authenticity of the Italian cuisine here is fantastic! I throughly enjoyed my dinner in the calm and low key environment in this gem of a restaurant.  Simple honest flavors.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. A fresh panzanella salad. Delicious!
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Wise guy pizza w/sopprasatta
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Campari spritzer

GYU65cyAf9L9ENZtonnG2w.text: Great pizza. I've been wanting to try the original place for a long time.  I am a NY pizza snob so usually wood fired is just okay in my book.  This is different. The crust stands up and stays crispier longer then most wood fired pizzas.  We took a big group and they did an amazing job.    We had the biancoverde pizza. Ricotta, mozzarella, olive oil base and arugula.  5 stars.   Margherita pizza was perfect. Mozzarella,sauce and basil. Simple and great. 5 stars   The parpadelle Bolognese was absolutely perfect. The noodles were cooked well and the sauce was great.  6 stars if I could.   The gnocchi special with sausage was tasty.  5 stars.   The Antipasto was also very good. Salami, goat cheese and warm vegetables. 5 stars.   Mozzarella and tomato salad 4 stars.   Spedini skewers.  Fontina wrapped in prosciutto cooked in the wood oven. 5 stars.   Braciole special. Our least favorite. Tender and fall apart but dry. The polenta and sauce were dynamite. More like pot roast then the dish I grew up eating. 3 stars.   Great place with good service. Will be back when I am in town.

9dvoyUUP2MB0tmvXQUszVw.text: Always lived down the block and never made it to Pizzeria Bianco at this location on 20th st. I finally went for dinner one evening, and I had the best time and best meal. The service was friendly and the food was even tastier. Being a high leveled Italian food critic, I commend Pizzeria Bianco. I enjoyed this dinner with some friends and everything we ordered was delectable.   We tried an the mozzarella and 2 pizzas, Homemade mozzarella, tomato and basil topped with EVOO Margarita Wiseguy   The ambiance was dark and romantic, such a wonderful place!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Pizza for the soul

m6QMKco6GdTkMWuJ6bPSLA.text: Best pizza in Arizona. Amazing and local family owned restaurant. Their crust is perfect and they make their house made tomato sauce is amazing.   I highly recommend the sunny boy and the rosa for pizzas. Also; their market salad never disappoints! Also; you can grab a loaf of bread for $5 and make yummy sandwiches later!  TLDR: eat here, it's great.

G0D7t0-T4a1Nr1srvm2fIw.text: Came from LA on a bachelor party and this was our first spot to grub as soon as we came off the plane. And OMGGGG I'm so happy we did.   Bianco is a very unique and quality Neapolitan pizza joint. All their pizzas have that char on the crust which you will only get on a wood fire oven. Excellent.   Highly recommend the pistachio pie and and the arugula pizza.

krL22uxE_10KbE9nb3E8tA.text: Absolutely no gluten free options for pizza or pasta. The menu is extremely abbreviated although the server expressed there were "tons" of gluten free options that weren't pizza or pasta. A chicken leg meal is $26 and $29 for a pork tenderloin. This place doesn't even have tablecloths or matching salt and pepper shakers.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States

bRE5xzPl2sZj7m0lHNrw8w.text: This is one of my favorites always good.  I usually rate based on food, service and environment and to get a 5 star review you must be amazing.  Best pizza I. AZ.    Enjoy.

bUkrNM2ioyeaDdJx7WtSaQ.text: This place was named as THE best pizza in the nation.  Let that sink in for a second.  How could you NOT come eat here without having high hopes?  I know it's not fair to the restaurant since it's critics and foodies that have given them that title, but it is what it is.    I would by no means rate their pizza as the best.  Not even the top 10.  But that's just me.  Maybe The Old County Inn pizza from Pine, AZ ruined the Bianca experience.  Both pizzas are made in a wood fire oven but Bianca lacked flavor.  The crust was good but other than that there really wasn't anything that made it any better than a chain like "wood fire pizza" such as Blazed.  For a one size pizza, the most basic one starts at $14.  It's a personal sized pizza...  really?  $14?!?!  I didn't think it was worth it at all. The rest of the menu had nothing else appetizing on it, hopefully because they're trying to stick to perfecting their pizza...  hopefully.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States

Pg1n-_QDBkmig1VfsJhFuA.text: I love just about every item on the menu- especially their Rosa pizza and small plate items. The tomato mozzarella salad is a favorite as well, so fresh!   As a long time resident of Phoenix, I'm proud that we have eateries that are recognized by larger cities and the Bianco brand reps us well. What I love most about this business is the family's commitment to helping other local restauranteurs by way of collaboration. Teaming up with others is the best way to build the sense of community that Phoenix has always been in need of.

hlhLMcx3ta-EhwK7XuaGIQ.text: Went for lunch and 3 of us shared a Margarita Pizza and a Biancoverde Pizza both were devoured. From the tasty thin crust on both to fresh tomato sauce and basil on the Margarita pizza and fresh arugula and ricotta on the Biancoverde pizza. Both pizzas were delicious and simple. We had cappuccinos which were also good and the service was excellent; the staff made sure we had everything we needed. We will definitely return.

g8o893osmWGZwiFpqFC4hA.text: Maybe not the best pizza in America as one publication but it was pretty great. It's hard to make a bad wood fired pizza but it's harder to make a great one. Not the most original toppings but the crust and sauce were excellent.

ccF5k6KJ9nX_Ybruj6TPUA.text: Came here for a work lunch during the week. Ironically, none of us in the group ordered pizza that this place seems to be known for. I ended up getting the House Made Pappardelle which had beef and parmesan cheese. I thought it was okay, nothing special about it. My group was seated in the back room, with a cute, dining room feel.  I definitely plan to return at one of these locations to try the pizza.   Parking is free in a shared lot with a bunch of other restaurants and grocery shops in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Surrounding stores &amp; restaurants
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Decor in the back dining room.

bykt7zAnhmHxHY99zE_XFg.text: This is easily the best pizza I've had. The margarita is amazing and has won awards from Rachel Ray and others as the best pizza in US. I've been here a few times. The service is spotty in that I've had fantastic service here and very rude service. The restaurant itself is not very comfortable with hard wood chairs. However, you come for the pizza which is the best in Phoenix and probably the US.

l1wm_Hb9ruFu9j0P-WqIlg.text: Well I've been told this is the best pizza around and I agree!   Decided to stop in to their Camelback location for an early lunch (you know it takes a couple days to move from that Eastern time zone!).  They open at 11a so we were all over it.   Great pizza with a side of tomato sauce (just in case) and a couple glasses of wine.  Outdoor patio was just the right mix of shade and sun and our server was super attentive.  When we are in town we will definitely be back!!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States

053ESh-l6w4QJEMIhJO6-Q.text: The pizza here is amazing.  The three or four pasta dishes i have had have been as well. Went this evening for takeout and got a couple of pizzas and the special pasta of the night (a bucatini with tomatoes and onions.). Got back to my hotel and tried the food. Pizza was its normal excellent level.   The pasta however was extremely bland.  All the other flavors were well balanced but there was no salt in the dish.  After raiding my hotel room and finding some, it was excellent.   I have no problem paying $22 for pasta if its delish.  However an omission of something as basic as salt from a dish like this - chef please check your line!!

ajHBXfluzek3buLQlMJSPg.text: Believe the hype! Honestly this will be some of the best pizza you will have in your life. Their pasta is fabulous as well. I also loved the decor in this location. Make sure you get sat in the back dining room. It was so beautiful and romantic. Lit entirely by candle light, the paintings and fire place make you feel like you are having an intimate diner in someone's home. Between the food and the ambiance, it will be the closest you can get to being in Europe without buying a ticket!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States

MvcPuCch6PMIoVqTWbMPEQ.text: I was super exited to check this place out but the food was a little on the underwhelming side. I had the veggie lasagna and it was just ok. My friends ordered the pizza and I tried the margarita pizza and once again that was just ok. What I can say was amazing was their homemade mozzarella with local tomato and basil. Anyway, aside from the good the service was great and our host was super attentive. I'm a sucker for great customer service but I just wished the food lived up to my expectations.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States

KN1UjWPPAWGPR6vEYrk9dw.text: I'm a fan and if I had this place in NY, I'd be eating carbs like crazy.   Visited Phoenix recently, awesome town BTW! but before I left I had to make sure I went to Pizzeria Bianco.   Couple of friends here in NYC raved and swore I had to go. They all know I'm obsessed with pizza, pasta and all the artistic beauty of Italia.   Took 1 hour to get a table for 2. I literally had two hours to get to the airport and begged them to let me sit at the bar so I can try the pizza. The pizza was amazing! Just like how they do in Italy. Finito.

dL_w-_Q4QZNXvXS-YoRljA.text: Full disclaimer: I have not eaten nor stepped foot in this restaurant.  However, one thing we already learned: if you have a big group that wants to eat at Pizzeria Bianco, consider other places.  On call #1, they directed us to their website to fill out a form.  Call #2 was a followup because we had not heard anything after more than 24 hours.  We provided our information and were assured we would hear back.  Over 72 hours later and still no call back which lead to call #3 to re-confirm the info.  So 3 calls, over 6 days, 1 online request and many broken assurances by two different staff persons and the non responsive ones too.  Pizzeria Bianco has a lot of business, but they won't get ours!

exC4bxkxj6GwMTLCQRlYjQ.text: This place is fantastic! Great service, adorable patio and the food was phenomenal! Pasta is homemade...I particularly enjoyed the gnocchi.

-GuGBk6JsMjmR_jAJvyIRA.text: Cute little joint wedged inside a strip mall.  Was visiting here from NYC for a conference with a bunch of coworkers, had heard about this place and wanted to check it out. Being from NYC we all had ridiculously high standards when it comes to pizza. We were not disappointed.   We tried the biancoverde and sausage pizzas. Great smoky woodsy crust and very simple and delicious toppings. Highly recommend.

lu2MK7RTrMuZQiVGC3rcaA.text: Our table for two was very small, and it was a little noisy, but the food was pretty amazing.  I had the gnocchi in brown butter with pancetta and some of my friend's pizza.  It's pricy, but I'll be back ordering pizza as my entree next time!  If the parking lot at the front of Town & Country is full, park in the back on the LA Fitness side, where there's also covered parking by the hotel, or on the Sleep America side of Whole Foods.  A little walk won't hurt after a hearty Italian meal!

oRMX5chC7odG1DUtmLtx3g.text: Great pizza, great char on the crust, this is as good as it gets. The local produce, the pasta dishes. Everything is excellent. And this location usually doesn't have a long wait if any.

0tnB3HjwKfHRsEhWyqfcrA.text: Ok I really don't get it ! Best Pizza in the what ??? I feel bad giving an A-ok because they deserve better than that , but I wasn't really a "Fan"/ The Bianco Verde Pizza was really good , but I think Cibo is way better . I assume Pizzera Bianco was one of the first gourmet pizza restaurants in Phoenix and that's when the hype started. There are so many just as great places in the valley and will cost you less than $20.00 a pizza. Another Note :I was the only customer at the restaurant and the waiter disappeared for 25+ minutes after the food was served. I had my lil one with me and had to flag someone inside to get a box and check.

jLTYYkiBxLoWd49KBH3cAA.text: The pizza was absolutely delicious as expected and the mozzarella was dreamy ! However, the treatment we received horrible !   We had never been before , so my husband and I ordered a pizza to share,  since we are not big eaters. It was clearly not enough. So get this....we tried to order another pizza and were told "no, there are too many people waiting". We were given are check and the table was cleared!    I don't care how good your pizza is!!! You can lump it for such rude behavior!! I would rather get a Dominoe's Death Disk before I would return.

UMLZ9KKLazQxxrTxXvRiTQ.text: WOW!  This restaurant has a well-earned reputation.  Having eaten pizza in some of the best restaurants in New York, Chicago (and God forbid California), I have to say that this restaurant does beat them all hands down.  Let's get to the pizza.  Wood fired oven.  Great crust.  Fresh mozzarella.  Unbelievably flavorful tomato sauce.  Fresh basil.  Perfectly cooked.  Yes.  Absolutely.  Best.  Pizza.  Ever.  And because we came on a Sunday, we got to have the Sunday Gravy.  This is a meat sauce made with the trimmings of sausage, brisket, meat.  It's a deep, dark tomato sauce, slow cooked, and just rich as all hell.  Over some fresh pasta.  Just an excellent pasta dish that we shared among all four of us.  Service was impeccable.  The environment was like a campagna according to the wife.    Wish I could give this place 6 stars.  Maybe I'll dock a star off of all of my other ratings.

b_r3vvcBJdIILREMbXEpbg.text: I know this isn't the original location but I was hangry and couldn't wait. First of all, I'm excited there are decent places to eat in arizona (I'm a CA native). I went on Saturday night. No wait at all. Ordered and pizza came out without 5 minutes! What?! I was so happy you have no idea how hungry I was. Waiters were attentive but I was too far in la la land with my slice of margherita pizza to notice anything else. Wow! Tomato sauce makes this pizza. On point! Thin crust goodness. I can't even form real sentences right now cause I'm too busy drooling! Lol yum they have an extensive wine list and other drinks too. Oh this lady next to me tho ate only the insides of her pizza and left the crust, actually putting the crust back together into a circle. Blasphemy! Please don't. The crust was the best.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Margherita mmm

xx905xP_XjBBxTxyZNW9vQ.text: Me and my husband decided to try this place for lunch today. We had just left trader joes and were looking for a quick bite to eat. We walked in to check their menu and were hooked after seeing the wood fire oven and the smell of the pizza. We shared the Margherita pizza. First I want to say I was very pleased that our sever knew that all of their cheeses were pasteurized. Most franchises we go to have no clue what I mean when I ask. Secondly, I loved that they served the bread and oil before our meal pizza came out. Third, the pizza tasted sooo fresh. We loved the mozzarella cheese and my husband didn't hesitate to grab my end crust before I put it down on my plate. Highly recommended.

REm5RQgBcQQ0SfFPy4ordg.text: I like the ambiance a lot and the server was attentive, but I wasn't satisfied with the pizza. I ordered a wise guy, which is fennel sausage and onions and mozzarella. The crust was thin but every bite I took had like a charred taste and when you look underneath, there was burned spots. The onions were too big and the toppings were not evenly spaced out, so there were toppings sliding and falling. It just wasn't my favorite pizza.

rKxidiWmM7CSGJAiF9PpWg.text: The first time my family and I strolled past this place, we assumed it had to be really good. With an hour and a half wait time, many people were willing to stay and wait for a table.  So, we decided to eat here the next day. It did not disappoint! The service was great and every dish we ordered was delicious. The Sonny Boy was full of flavor. The pasta was amazing. The mozzarella tasted freshly made. The asparagus came with a Sunny Side Up egg on top, which I wouldn't think to do, but the side was very tasty.  I'm not one to wait an hour and a half for a table at a restaurant, but I understand why someone would for this place.

y7qJZxuQZV3g5rmm7bWAhg.text: I've loved the downtown location for years so when the new location opened I was excited to try it. I have been to the new location a handful of times now and its amazing every time. I have had several pasta dishes, pizzas, salads, antipasto platter, and desserts, all of which were outstanding.   Out of the 5 or so times I've been I've had one bad service experience and I don't blame he server, he was very overwhelmed after the restaurant received a random rush on a week night. Other than that it really seems like they are getting a hold on this place. I know it was a little off at first but it is definitely on point now.   If you have never tried the downtown location or are already a Bianco lover you have to try this location. I've never waited more than a half an hour for a table and the food is just...sigh...the best.

djHfWsdPq_cqsbTXMDwJiA.text: So we were looking forward to coming here for dinner because it is the same owner as the Pizzeria Bianco downtown Phoenix (which I love). When you first walk up, you immediately feel the same type of intimate and cozy NY style eatery. The decor is not overbearing and classically simplistic. Its not large and there is not a ton of seating inside, with also a few tables outside on their patio. we did not have to wait which was a bit of a surprise but in a good way. We were seated just off of the middle of the room and greeted fairly quickly by our waiter.  After a few minutes of thought, we decided upon a bottle of wine per the waiter's recommendations. However, to my surprise (being a fellow wine connoisseur) when I tasted it, it had not a single notation of how he described it to be. It was not slightly acidic, there was no dark fruit notes, nor the structure we were looking for. However, I hate being 'that person' who causes issues when dining out. So naturally, we drank it. C'est la vie.  Next, we ordered an appetizer. It was hot figs filled with Manchego cheese paired with fresh arugula and sliced prosciutto. OMG, it was fantastic! Just the aromatics alone made you feel like you were temporarily transported to soe small Venetian town. As for our entrees, the same canot be said. I was again, persuaded into ordering the gnocchi that our server swore by and the other dish was their beef bracole. To my shock, my dish was luke warm at best, the gnocchi were tiny, and the entire dish was just greasy. The beef was 'OK' but had some interestingly enough more Latin flavors than Italian. Hmmmm.....  I did however want to give them one last chance so for dessert I ordered the dark chocolate flour-less cake... it was good, not great, but no real complaints there. Needless to say, the experience was only saved by the company I kept and that amazing fig appetizer. The value of this place is not great by any means... to spend what we did on disappointing food and service... tsk tsk... I really hope that our server tries to eventually learn more about flavor profiles and actually know what he is talking about instead of just saying random things that do not make sense.  I just try to call it like I see it... it was all in all a grand disappointment that did not live up to the almost Utopian culinary skills of the pizzeria downtown.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Prosciutto app

rX68ZIEfU6xB_ALyuPw5Xw.text: Chris Bianco opened this restaurant after the success of his downtown pizzeria. The menu here is expanded, and reservations are accepted.  I arrived @ 7:00 with two companions and was seated immediately. The waiter was friendly, and had a good knowledge of the food and how it was prepared. We decided to order several entree's and share them so that everyone could taste.  We ordered the Papparadelle with Bolognese Sauce, Beef Braciole or Involtini if you are in Italy, and a Pizza Margherita.  The Papparadelle came with fluted edges, cooked reasonably al dente, with an excellent Bolognese sauce loaded with chunks of meat. I found it to be on par with any I have ever eaten, though on a personal note I prefer the pasta to be more rustic and hand cut or torn into uneven "rags".  My companions did not care for the Beef Braciole as much as I did, but allowing for different tastes as well as living in vastly different locations, I can accept that.  I found the meat to be beautifully cooked, nicely presented on a bed of cooked cauliflower, and served with some properly roasted onions.  Many people who make this dish tend to overpower it with lots of cheese and bread crumbs wrapped up in the beef.Unlike many variations on this recipe, this one was not overly salted or spiced, which I personally appreciated, as the flavor of the range fed beef came out nicely.  Many reviewers have said that the pizza is the best in the United States. I would differ with that opinion. Certainly, the pizza is very good, but I've eaten many a pizza that I felt was as good. The crust has a good flavor, is nicely thin with a nice edge, but the one we were served had an undercooked center that flopped down when picked up. The cheese is handmade on the premises, and is a real treat, melting into a lacy puddle swimming in a pool of an excellent sauce.   My biggest criticism was with the basil. This pizza is supposed to represent the Italian flag - 3 colors - red (sauce), white (cheese) and green (basil). The pizza was cut into 6 pieces and 5 leaves of basil were put on it. One person would not get a real piece of pizza margherita. Worse still, to me is that you only get a leaf of basil. Which bite do you eat it with? In my mind, the best pizza margherita I have ever eaten had a chiffonade of basil sprinkled all over it, so that you got some basil with each bite. My understanding is that that is how the pizza was supposed to be made originally. You wouldn't serve the queen one leaf of basil, now would you?  I must make mention of the bread that came with the meal. I don't know if it is made on the premises or not, but it was wonderfully crusty, with a chewy interior and a superior texture. It was served with a little extra virgin olive oil, and was really excellent.  Overall, the premises were clean, though a little noisy at times. I'm hoping that Chris will put a whole lot more basil on his pizza's, as that is a basic part of the flavor of it.  4 stars for excellent service, good food, and general cleanliness.

tpODIFXArzxCrWbQIttosA.text: While on a road trip, I recently got to check off Pizzeria Bianco from my bucket-list. OMG! I loved it so much and only wish I lived closer to have it again. I've had some good pizza before from Neapolitan to New York-style to dining on it throughout Italy. They're all good in their own ways, and the margherita pizza I had here was right up there with the very best. I love love loved the crust texture, the sauce and the just-right amount of cheese. I could weep, it was so delish. Doesn't go with pizza, but we had margaritas with the margherita and they hit the spot after a long day on the road. Our server couldn't have been more helpful. The bartender even came over, after seeing we needed more napkins, and without being asked, dropped some off. It's located in what looked like an upscale mall with an exterior entrance. I didn't see much after we found their location as I had a one-track mind--get that pizza in my face.

1iIp-_bk3MNXiO-Ze9CN7g.text: Let's start with the pizza, since it is a pizzeria. I had the opportunity to taste several of them from the classic margherita pizza to the wiseguy topped with smoked mozzarella and fennel sausage. I do have to say it was good. The dough is made fresh with fresh ingredients and everything is handcrafted. But what makes the pizza is the wood fire oven which gives it a delicious light charred taste. The appetizers were also very good but the portions are small like the Spiedini but still delicious. Finally we did have dessert and we ordered the lemon curd this was a bit sour for my taste and I would difinintly order something different next time. The service was great and everyone seems to be on point when it comes to knowing the business. Overall great food pleasant atmosphere with inspiring decor. Come check it out when in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Pleasant decor.
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Pork ciccoli with fresh slaw and quince fruit purea.
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Margherita pizza with a side of fennel sausage.

MNdizsRvUy4dDVFKSV5GEQ.text: First time there to celebrate a birthday event for a party of 6.  Never again!  We brought a special cake that the birthday person had requested.  Before we even sat down we were told by the rude manager/host that no outside dessert was aloud but they would make a one time exception for us.  He came across as if he was doing us a big favorite.  He didn't even bother to say "Happy Birthday" or did he care that we were his first time customers that will not be returning.  NO PIZZA IS WORTH IT!!!  The food was good but it was not the best meal we have ever had.  The market pasta was $21.00 but nothing to rave about or worth that price.  There are plenty of good restaurants with great service in Phoenix that we could have gone to.  For example:  Federal, Parlor and LGO.

GdViv43uWwhCogLVv26kxg.text: I visited here a few weeks back while I was in town as I've heard the food is amazing but I am sad to say that we were really let down. Not by the food but by the service alone.   Two friends and I visited on a week night (I believe it was a Tuesday) and we were seated quickly on the outside patio and brought menus. Very simple menu which is a plus. Between the three of us we ordered a pizza and some pasta and a few drinks. We found it to be a little pricey and over rated but all in all we happy with the food.   The place was not very crowded this night either - the patio tables seemed to be occupied and the inside had a handful of table occupied as well. Not too slow, not too busy.   Service seemed to be good until we neared the end of our meal. Our plates were cleared away once we had finished the food (as expected) and our check was dropped off at the table. We were still drinking our drinks while enjoying conversation, paid our bill, then just a few short moments later our glasses and drinks were all removed from the table without our request. The server straight up cleared our entire table without saying a single word to us. It was a moment where we were not only confused as to why she was doing this but also very irritated. It not only made us feel very uncomfortable but unwelcome. We immediately regretted the huge tip that we left.   We would have understood if the place was at capacity, there was a wait to be seated and they needed the table but that was not the case at all.  We clearly got the vibe she was sending (and it wasn't a good one), picked up our stuff and left. My husband (someone who has been working in restaurant management for the last 15+ years) was very uneasy about what had just happened and as we were walking out to leave he turned back around and asked to speak with a manager. He explained the situation to the "manager" there but it was evident he didn't seem to really care as he didn't try one bit to remedy the situation or change our minds on their establishment. Worst choice he could have made right there.  I've never ever encountered such rude service in my life and this is coming from someone who eats out at restaurants quite frequently.   Needless to say we were all very very disappointed. I'd never visit this place again or recommend it due to their lack of respect and service alone.

fpwPNkB3iktXleBr6zjfkA.text: I've been to the original and the one off of Camelback, and neither have disappointed. Their food is authentic Italian (growing up with an Italian mother, I would know) and they're pizzas are to die for. It's a need to try for everyone of every age!

Oe2r7vgeW51R57dVsVg2Pg.text: This place had been on my radar for 15 years, after seeing Chris Bianco win the James Beard award in 2003 and also seeing his first location featured on the Food Network getting some interesting press for only offering five types of pizzas each day - served to mobs of people. Well, I've been coming to Phoenix a lot recently for work and imagine my delight when I walked by this place a couple of blocks from my office and hotel. CUE JAZZ HANDS. This place is magical. First time, I sat outside on their adorable patio and was served a cute little bowl of tangy olives before my pizza arrived. Second time, I sat at the bar and was served some incredible fresh bread and olive oil before my pie. The more carbs, the merrier. They still have five pizzas each day (spelled out in alphabet magnets on the wall in front of the pizza oven) plus one special, though it's hard for me to stray from my favorite of all pizzas, the humble margherita ($14). I've eaten it plain and also once added the wood fired mushrooms (+$3). Both excellent. I didn't leave a speck on my plate either visit. Delicious charred crust, but not TOO charred. Enough fresh mozzarella to make the middle a hair soggy and plenty of basil leaves. I've had very friendly servers who made just enough casual conversation for a solo diner not to feel awkward. Excellent wine, beer and cocktail list. This was such a treat for me to finally visit and I will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States

WaMC30ioONPKijhS74NoGQ.text: Still perfect after all these years. Chris Bianco's international reputation is well-deserved.  The Sonny Boy pizza is my favorite though the Wise Guy comes a close second. The crust is impeccable. The house red wine is excellent and for dessert don't pass up the flourless chocolate cake with vanilla bean cream for dessert. You cannot beat it.

N6m1N0VVEe-Itn8YH1ojgA.text: This was the first spot we tried when we moved to Phoenix. We shared the Biancoverde, it was delicious, definitely one of the best pies I've ever eaten! More of an upscale date night place though, good for special occasions/night out!

Q1_kr2DKRmQJyOC9V5VV5Q.text: Excellent. Kind and knowledgeable staff, clear and concise menu with special care to keep it simple. The pizza was as phenomenal as was the pasta. 4 stars only because the seating was uncomfortable after 30 mins, minor gripe but this restaurant deserves a good investment in furniture. Fabulous restaurant for sure.

F4ARci74c2iJPyOuk99rNg.text: I honestly do not understand the people that say this place is good. They obviously have NEVER had good Italian food. The appetizer bread is cold and the oil is watered down. The food is as bland as can be. Order some Dominoes, better pizza than this place. Nice ambiance but that can not justify the food.

X4hUPj0LN3HvxYf3cJWoTQ.text: Pizzeria Bianco was once described as pizza nirvana, I'm not sure if I agree with this but I did see a blinding white light of happiness. The vision was in a shape of a pie. Thus, I probably had a pizza stroke. The perfect crust coming out of the wood fired oven brought back my sight. Biancoverde and Wiseguy are slices you shouldn't ever refuse. Pizzeria Bianco has a relaxing vibe and a tranquil Italian countryside atmosphere, so mayhaps I was in pizza heaven.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States

gSz3wg8lFEEG92Dk02mvvQ.text: Pizzeria Bianco review for the 4743 N 20th St location in Phoenix, AZ.  My girlfriend and I have been living in Phoenix for roughly 3 weeks now. As a massive pizza fan, I've been using the website to check out the most acclaimed places the city has to offer. This location, although mildly rated worse than its sister location, seemed like a great place to check out after having the fantastically fresh-made pizza from "The Parlor".  Needless to say, I was beyond disappointed.   We both ordered the Margherita, which is essentially a cheese pizza with basil leaves. We waited roughly 20 minutes for the food, during which we were given 2 rounds of their fresh made bread and olive oil for free, which was probably the highlight of the visit.  Taste-wise, it's fresh brick oven pizza. Good, but not great by any means. The crust tastes fine, but mine was slightly burnt on one slice, while my girlfriends looked pretty black all the way around like it'd spent extra time in the oven. The amount of ingredients was acceptable, but sparse in my opinion. 5 large basil leaves scattered around the 12'' pie. Cheese and sauce were pretty good, but what else would you expect from fresh mozzarella and tomato sauce?  The kicker is that this meal was $16 dollars per pizza! Absolutely absurd in my opinion for what they give you. Our meal came out to roughly $35 dollars with no drinks purchased.  Can't speak for the rest of the menu, but the pizza isn't worth the price here.

3oKuGsvA2qB8k9dLGdakoQ.text: Mixed review.  Long wait to finally get a seat.  Restaurant is very small.  The red sauce pizzas were without question very good.  The white pizzas we ordered were not as good as we had hoped.  Very busy place in the historic district.

vFlVXNVyDrqA3hZs9guh6g.text: I had apprehensions about going here because the hype that surrounds Pizzeria Bianco.  I'm typically very skeptical when you hear a pizza place talk so much about their dough.  But I gotta say....I really enjoyed that pizza.  I ordered a half Rosa half Margherita (sp?) pizza.  I read on Phoenix New Times that the Rosa was one of the 50 dishes in Metro Phoenix I "had to try".  It didn't sound too appetizing to me, so I only ordered half of it.  But after tasting it, I wish I had just ordered the whole Rosa.  The other half was good too.  I love the tomato sauce they use, but the Rosa was out of this world tasty.  You have to try it once just to at least say you tried it.  It was a very flavorful experience.

rwYHbIPCV4PRSxLPDsdOQg.text: I really have to wonder if some of the people reviewing this place and calling the pizza 'tasteless' have any taste buds at all? The Rosa is the single best pie i've ever had, and to boot is an ingenious combination of salty & bitter flavors. Not that any of that makes a difference for these pizza n00bs' unrefined palates. The fact that this Town & Country treasure has a full star less on this site than the likes of Hopdoddy and Grassroots just proves that crowdsourcing restaurant reviews isn't always such a good idea.

liUgpkHHKL1zwkFIrt1_8A.text: The travel gods were really smiling on me today!  First, I dodged the bullet on having to sit next to the world's most annoying preschooler on the plane.  Next, I scored a double upgrade at the car rental place and am driving a little 3-series for the next few days.  Finally, I was referred to this place by a couple of Phoenix Yelpers who were kind enough to respond to my request on the local talk page.  I started with a beautifully fresh salad of locally-grown greens with a delicate dressing.  The star of the show had to be the three olives I found under the greens.  Each one was a slightly different color and flavor.  All were delicious and they were so tender!  Apparently they are from a distributor in California the chef selected based on the quality of their products.  In my humble opinion it was a great choice.  The salad was bg enough to split so I just ate half to save room for the pizza.   Bread service with a really impressive olive oil that also comes from the same distributor in California.  None of that wimpy light-colored olive oil here.  This place is bringing out a richly green olive oil with a fragrance and taste similar to what is found in Europe.  I controlled my bread-loving impulses and limited myself to just one piece to ensure I had plenty of room for the pizza.   Next up... the main event!  The pizza arrived with a sage word of advice: let it sit for 1 minute before digging in.  Based on my view of this pie, that minute probably ranks among the top ten hardest minutes of my life.  I so wanted to dig right in but I hate biting into a pizza too soon and burning the skin off the roof of my mouth.  After feasting, I grilled my server to be sure I really understood the experience.  He has been with the owner for 18 years and is a partner in the restaurant so he nailed every answer to my questions with a phenomenal amount of detail and enthusiasm!  Here are the highlights:  - Sea salt in the dough is responsible for the slight saltiness of their crust.  It is crunchy and chewy at the same time.  Slightly bubbly around the edges and very thin in the middle.  - The wiseguy does not include sauce (olive oil instead - odd in a pizza with sausage and caramelized onions on top of it) but they use a variety of their house-made mozzarella that they smoke in their oven.  If you find yourself inhaling slightly before taking a bite you will pick up the smokiness immediately.  Pretty amazing!   - The sausage is locally produced using a recipe the chef/owner devised.   Lots of fennel here... always a good omen for an Italian sausage being served to a native Chicagoan. They split them,  dress with a little olive oil and then into the oven they go.  After they cool,  they are sliced and used to top the pizza such that they go through the oven a second time and pick up a slight crispness around the edges.  The result is sausage like you rarely find on pizza and pure perfection if you can open your mind to other than bulk sausage appearing on top of your pie...not that I have anything against bulk sausage.   - The Margarita pizza involved a finely-blended fresh tomato sauce that goes on raw and cooks in their 800-degree oven.   - The basil comes from a local farmer who let's it grow until it resembles a bush before harvesting,  thus producing leaves that looked to be about twice the size of the basil I grow at home.  They were very generous with those large leaves and that just served to make the pie that much better.  I was really impressed, Phoenix.  This place would be in the rotation if I lived here.  I'm also glad that I tried their expansion joint instead of the original place because I received far more patience with my questions than I'm sure I would have received at the downtown location.  Sadly, the flourless chocolate cake eluded me - I was just too damn full and happy to eat another bite.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Half wiseguy and half margherita... all delicious!

Xd2wNypcq4Zxg0i3XY2FuQ.text: I have been waiting a long time to finally try Pizzeria Bianco. This review is for the Town & Country location rather than the downtown location. The restaurant is big and open with indoor and outdoor seating. It has a larger menu than the downtown location, but we were here for the pizza.  We had the Wiseguy and Rosa pizzas. The pizzas are rather large and have a great thin crust. Both of us agreed that the Rosa had a lot of flavor with the pistachios, cheese, and oil. The Wiseguy was rather bland, even with the sausage and smoked onions. The onions would be great on another pizza though. Both did not have a tomato sauce, but it was not missed. You can save the crusts to sop up all the olive oil remaining on the plate too.  This place deserves most of the hype, although I would not wait in a long line for it. The other location probably has more atmosphere, but this location is a great way to get the food without the fuss.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Rosa in Foreground; Wiseguy in Background

ar54MacRbkIjz6sImTARpg.text: Loooooved it loved it loved it. Is it the best pizza in the United States? I don't know but it's pretty damn good. We went on a Saturday afternoon with a group of 7 guys and ordered all of the pizzas and two pastas as well as house white wine - brilliant. The bread is also amazing. My favorite was the Rosa with pistachios followed by the Wiseguy. The pastas - all homemade were excellent too.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Biancoverde - awesome
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Marinara - so good and great flavor
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Pasta special - amazing

6AUXStZYv26aG-j7WJsXqg.text: Such a nice place to come to with a big group! We came with 13 girls and no reservation. They were able to sit us almost right away and service was outstanding! We came for a birthday dinner and Pizzeria Bianco went above and beyond to make our experience amazing. Complementary mozzarella for the whole table and then a birthday dessert to finish up. Rolando and Adam took great care of us! We'll be back!

5ciMaJlnY_vLWuDjLkjnhQ.text: It was good. But the best pizza in North America, not sure I would go that far but then again I think dominos is pretty good.  Service was excellent and I  really enjoyed the appetizer, it was amazing. Just can't remember what it was called.

u56CRmbyEMXq0s-DhPh87g.text: Just had the best lasagna ive ever had.  It melted in my mouth it was so good!!! Bravo Pizzeria Bianco!!!!

wqGs4vypOgm3NkG_UOk5pQ.text: The best pizza in town! I am very pleased at every visit. I like to come here with a group of several people to be able to taste as many dishes as possible.  My favorite appetizer is Caprese salad. Their fresh mozzarella is really good, taste like homemade, mixed with very good olive oil makes it so perfect. Speaking of olive oil, I always like their olive. It reminds of me what my mother-in-law used to make at home.  They are so good, in fact, even those who don't normally eat olives liked their olives.  They are that good.  My favorite pizza is biancoverde. I like arugula, and eat them as salad often. Garlic paste they use matches arugula and cheese really well.  For desert, can't miss the flourless chocolate cake. 80% of dark chocolate gives you just right  amount of sweetness.  I also like their coffee. I haven't had a chance to ask about beans they use but I can tell they use really good coffee beans.  Service is always good, location is convenient (near 51 and Camelback), this is a must try at least once place.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. My ultimate favorite biancoverde
Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. With homemade cheese, yum

y9FRpZ546aZqeK5dDEYucw.text: Long time fan, friend and customer, but I have never had a large party dinner here until the other night. Total party was 12 people and it was fantastic! The food is always fresh, delicious and plentiful. The bartender was making excellent drinks. The cocktails were unique and refreshing. Sitting at the bar before everyone arrived and watching him mix his concoctions was impressive. The wait staff was phenomenal and ultra attentive; water glasses were never empty, drinks were never left unattended and the food flow was awesome. From appetizers to dessert and coffee everything was perfect. Typically it is just my wife and I or with another couple, but I highly recommend  hosting a large group anytime its available. Looking forward to our next visit!

zrKz0h7dfedD4EwFfR62Uw.text: What is there to say that hasn't been said? I just want to add my voice to the chorus of love for this amazing pizza place. Of course the dough is perfect: tender on the inside, crispy light cornicone, and seasoned. The sauce is lightly sweet and thinly laid. The Rosa is my absolute favorite, and I apologize for ever doubting the idea of nuts on a pizza, because here, they totally work.   I happen to prefer this location because I never have a problem getting a seat.

gqEJIVduMb4nr2uDs5qA1w.text: Service was 5 star! Ask for Dave.  We shared the evenings special, Braciole, flank steak from heaven, YUMM. This is worth the drive from anywhere.  I had the  PappaDelle, basically very meaty sauce with lasagna pasta. Nice.  To round out dinner we added a margarita pizza. Nothing better than wood fired pizza and thin crust.  I gotta be honest, the focaccia bread was my favorite. I should have stooped there!  As the duke, I must recommend!

0_o4IBU_DlKLD0oiqvvhIg.text: Formerly known as "Italian Restaurant" this is the only Italian restaurant I will go to in the valley.  I'm sure there is some very nice Italian at other restaurants, but this is mine.  Always an authentic dining experience, never overwhelmed with pasta and always served delicious homemade favourites.  This is my favourite local Italian family to support.  Speaking of, I think it's time for another visit. :)

qQo8o-GmP3_5pkZWIh6oiA.text: We were visiting Phoenix for MLB spring training and the restaurant was right around the corner from our hotel.  Decided to try it based on the yelp reviews.  We shared the margherita pizza.  The pizza was delicious with nice thin crust.

bTSbnYZejHDThGLQCyzscg.text: After a few attempts to get to the Pizzeria Bianco downtown, I was so pleased to happen upon this location. I finally, FINALLY got to see what the fuss was all about.  I'm giving this five stars because, really, it's five star pizza. It's every bit as delish as some of my other favorite pizza joints. I'm going to say that it didn't quite live up to my expectations, though. I was half-expecting a religious experience after all the hype. Alas, the sky didn't open up and I didn't hear the angels sing, but I did have some pretty freakin' awesome pizza, and I will definitely go again when I'm in the neighborhood.

Hm0c0sFA-A9WpX-GDZLg0A.text: Still delicious pizza. Today I had the Wise Guy pizza with wonderful sausage and onions. Does not disappoint at Pizzeria Bianco. You really must go.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizzeria Bianco - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Wiseguy pizza with sausage and onions.

_5nVcsAIqHoIFY0vyCNHRQ.text: I want to cry when I read reviews from other people stating that the pizza here was "amazing" or  was "perfection."  Lets start off with the ridiculous pricing. The pizza ought to be perfect for the prices Bianco charges.  $18.00 is what Bianco is charging for his Sonny Boy and Wise Guy pizzas.  Am I paying for the pizza or am I helping to pay Bianco's rent?  Interestingly, at his other restaurant Pane Bianco, prices for the pizzas are $2.00 less.  The Sonny Boy, which has sopressata and olives is what I decided to order after passing on the Wise Guy.  Upon ordering, the waiter informed me that the Wise Guy does not have sauce on it and that I could order a Margherita and get the fennel sausage on it for an additional $5.00 surcharge.  As I was not going to spend $20.00 for a pizza, I declined.  Upon getting the pizza, it was very tasty but far from perfect.  While I like a crust that has some char on it, this crust seemed not only burnt but very dry.  Additionally, at lunch time, the menu is incredibly limited which is a turn off.    Despite these things, the atmosphere was pleasant and waitstaff was great.   At the end of the day however, I doubt I will be back because I know I can get excellent pizzas at several other places in the valley without paying Bianco's exorbitant prices.

TgTMq_vlN4COxkZL_PLQ1w.text: Pretty good pizza although there is a small selection. Small selection is the key description for this restaurant. It's got a neat look to it but it isn't much if anything special.  I will stick with Humble Pie and Grimaldi's.

3U2J1MFWiKcDHhKImYY5IQ.text: Best pizza ever!! And amazing service also a very Italian atmosphere! Try the pistachio pizza it's soooooo good!! Love this place

DzQcCkuPO3sHTZHE9me2xw.text: Pizza is wood fired. It came out a little too burned. Kendall was great as our waitress. The papparadelli was tasty but a little too salty. The meatball sandwich was just ok.  The bread falls apart and you have to use a fork to eat it.  Can't say anything bad but nothing outstanding either. Would not come back.

D0YY8JKlgj-mdtaxoed4OQ.text: I don't get the hype associated with Chris but I digress. ( I love the sandwiches at Panne though)  My dinner partner is Italian and what she ordered she said was very good. I myself did not think mine was to die for. I must be jinxed and order the wrong thing every time I eat at one of Chris' restaurant. I have to admit though his hand pressed mozzarella, tomatoes and Italian sausage are high quality for AZ standards. Maybe I can just eat apps here. lol     The service was fine, nothing to write home about but not bad either. The restaurant is small. I felt squished. However, I have heard they are expanding. I have also heard they are adding pizza and Pannes to the menu! Woot, woot! Well, I guess I will keep trying Chris. I am determined to get a good pizza from you at least one time. We are not done with each other yet. lol!     Good luck on the new venture. I like the open kitchen and changing menu concept too. Four stars and a return trip guaranteed because you are better than most so called Italian places in sadly lacking Az. Also,if my picky, NY, Italian, makes pasta and gravy from scratch friend VK likes you, there has to be something there that I am missing.

GwWcopxD2vGdVQFaj61zOg.text: A longtime favorite of mine. So great to see him back in Town and Country. And I can now walk there.

ZjZYYZ7apsYtLCdvoTE7dQ.text: What won the night was the Fig on Rye. Delicious. Reminded me of the world's most expensive Dr.pepper.

na8JmuZ20rzUAtXeagnEMA.text: The location wasn't the easiest to find. The restaurant had a unique atmosphere to it. The food was great and the service was fast. Prices were what you would expect from an upscale pizzeria. Don't go in expecting your typical pizza choices. I'd definitely recommend the Biancoverde pizza.

yXhf7x5_wFOxaefI3MuwJg.text: I'll start this off by saying I really wanted to like this restaurant. After hearing mixed reviews I kept an open mind, but unfortunately was dealt a mediocre experience.   The interior was cute, however you can tell that whoever chose the furniture didn't sit in each seat beforehand. We were at what could have been a cute little Italy type of table, but it was SO little that everyone's knees could not fit underneath it. Definitely more little kid than little Italy.    Another atmosphere downer was how HOT it was inside. Granted it was 116 degrees outside but the open kitchen layout wasn't helping Bianco's case - nor was the server who kept opening the patio door.   I will say the food was the best part of our experience, however it was mediocre Italian at best. The spaghetti...was spaghetti. I'd make it at home before coming back to order. The gnochhi was the best dish at the table and it was the corn that really made it. The cavatelli was decent (but I was glad I didn't order it) and our friend who ordered the pappardelle was apparently pleased because he ate it all.  If you're a Bianco fan, I'd say give it a go - maybe you'll get a better table, a less awkward server and food worth going back for; it just didn't happen on our visit.

7loBnnWEyGF_psus4aPm-g.text: Nothing wrong with this place but it certainly isn't the best pizza in the country let alone AZ. It was OK at best - we have Antico's and Campanias here in the Atlanta area that are much better!  Crust is supposed to be a little burnt but ours was way over charred. Toppings were also a bit bland.

gjQTy2eAh8sIRT69xbZ3kw.text: Excellent pizza and service!    I am used to the three hour wait for pizza from Pizzeria Bianco, however after only 10 minutes we were able to get one of the best tables outside.  I'm sure this will change once word gets out on the new location, but for now it's easy to get in :)   We had the margarita, wiseguy and biancoverde pizzas and all were great!  My favorite is the margarita, it's very simple but the ingredients are amazing.  Second is the biancoverde (we were able to add the wood-roasted onions and it was awesome) and then the wiseguy...but I would highly recommend all three.  For dessert we had the chocolate cake and tiramisu with homemade cream.  Loved them both, can't go wrong with either.    Our waitress and both hostesses were great and I would go back again in a heartbeat!

AqQX4iArHKzOsovlTwR_fQ.text: The decor is great.  Very nice set up, its fun having a huge window where the kitchen is viewable from the mall side.  That said, the rest of it was not the best..  They give you a crostini appetizer/sample(?) with some kind of cheese on top.  It was super salty and not great... unsure what the point was..  They have Coke Light, I guess a naturally sweetened version of Diet Coke.  My friend ordered it and I was hemming and hawing and decided on the water.  He brought us 2 cokes anyway and charged for both.  I think part of the problem is there's no music, but the noise level is a bit high sometimes.  We had a hard time hearing half the things the waiter was saying and I'm sure it goes the other way as well.  So we tried the Cavatelli and the Gnocchi.  The cavatelli was not the best pasta, sausage pasta plate I've ever had.  The gnocchi got a bit old after a few bites.  Basically a bed of creamed corn, potato gnocchi and chunks of panchetta.  Not terrible, but gets old.  All in all, wouldn't go back.  The prices don't justify the lackluster pasta dishes.  They bring you 4 pieces of bread at a time (we had a table of 4 so we asked for like 2 refills).  The cheese plate is not very big, but tasty.  However, I thought they would bring us more bread for the cheese plate.. didn't happen, had to ask for it separately.  My friend's water glass didn't get filled all night, we tried moving it to the edge of the table too.  We had 4 different waiters and nobody can fill a water glass for over half the dinner?

vdv4R0NeQSPDXGxxfDxp4w.text: The German philosopher Johann Goethe remarked, "failure is not in falling down; failure is in not getting up again." Like a prize fighter, Chris Bianco's "Italian Restaurant" is getting up again after hitting the ropes. Word of mouth (and mediocre Yelp reviews) are a bitch to recover from, so I say let the reboot redemption begin -pronto.  Set back in a dark corner of the slightly schleppy "Town and Country Mall" (near Trader Joe's), Italian Restaurant is almost hard to find. Walking inside you find a place that does not scream out hipster or cool - but instead yawns with some old paintings that you might find at your cute old Nonna's villa in Naples - with a portrait of a Sophia Loren in her 60's eyeliner glory watching over the dark room. But the food should be the star, right?   If Pizzeria Bianco is Chris' shrine to the ultimate pie, then Italian Restaurant is his nod to the worship of wholesome and satisfying pastas - in the realm of the Nancy Silverton's consistently fantastic "Mozza" in Los Angeles - along with great salads and Apps.   Based on my supremely yummy dinner (especially the home made pastas) last week I would dare say that Italian Restaurant is now serving some of the most satisfying Italian food in Phoenix. As a matter of fact, this is the best Italian I have had since my old fave "Ninetta's" closed over 7 years ago (a hole in the wall at 7th Ave and Union Hills). I would strongly suggest you give this wonderful little Bianco gem a well deserved second chance at delighting your senses.  Let me first state clearly that fellow Yelpers and foodies seeking seeking over the top meals laced with just out of cooking school foamy ribbons and ideas straight from some Euro competition will be sorely disappointed. That was what the old (fired) chef Claudio Urciucoli tried with (what I have read on older Yelp reviews here) mixed results. The new chef Robbie Tutlewski is now in sync with the Bianco's vision - creating hearty meals that any Mamma would recognize in a prosecco.      Bianco is synonymous with simple and yet extremely well executed food that he trys to source locally whenever possible. This man and his gregarious (and much more outgoing) brother Marco are obsessed with growing their own arugula, their own San Marzano tomatoes (which Bianco and his partner in CA are now canning and selling to restauranteurs throughout the U.S.), and even now growing and milling their own wheat for the breads and pastas.   It seems that Bianco has realized that the sheer simplicity of creating traditional and tasty food staples better than anyone else - perfecting them to the highest possible level- with the freshest and tastiest local ingredients - is the secret to success.   Enough background - lets talk about the yummy meal. My wife and I joined another couple here and we ordered a variety of Antipasti: The Cheese Plate Mortada was a sampling of  cow, goat and sheep's milk cheeses - all delicious. The AZ Peach salad was a favorite at the table - local and very ripe cut peaches with fresh arugula and flecks of goat cheese with some candied pecans. This is a savory and sweet salad that is (as others have said) perfectly balanced and works like a dream. Yum!  The waiter (Adam I believe) also recommended the earthy grilled zucchini salad - which is complimented with fresh mint leaves, Montamore cheese (like a sharp cheddar) and topped with a sunny side up egg... which added just the right fatty texture and taste.   I think the pasta dishes are the strength at Italian Restaurant - easily some of the tastiest and best pasta in this town! Some people may not understand that the texture of fresh pasta is vastly different than the dried type that is most common - and from what I understand from Chris' brother Marco, the pastas here are made daily by a woman who's only job is to turn out these morsels of home made goodness. The wheat for these pastas is also fresh, and I believe Chris is now milling the flour too - who else would go to such lengths to bring us pasta that tastes like it was lovingly sourced  from the Italian countryside?   The "Cavatelli" is a big "O" in terms of flavors - pastas shaped almost like baby hot dog buns - slightly dense and al dente to the bite - served with bits of local Shreiner's sausage, roasted cauliflower and spring onions served up in what I'm guessing was a reduction of stock and a little cream - wow. Fantastic! The potato Gnocchi was pillowy and perfect, complimented by sweet corn and flecks of salty Pancetta.   The desserts we tried were all superb: A fresh peach crostata (like a tart) was buttery and amazing, and the Italian ices (all fresh) are extremely flavorful - the dense chocolate being my favorite. The flourless chocolate cake was excellent but also a little basic as that is standard fare at many restaurants.   Any Yelp reviews prior to May 1st reflect the old chef - come back and try Italian Restaurant soon while it is still easy to be seated. Cue Rocky theme music

QNH_8sU1LzD-SI_2t7GZMw.text: Awful service and food. We were a party of six and spent a $100 on pizza and salad. sorry to say that the pizza was bland and salad was awful. We asked for an extra scoop of dressing since what we got for the large salad for a 1 teaspoon of dressing. That included about ten pieces of lettuce and four shavings of vegetables. I am not sure what the fuss is about this place Nellos beats this anytime. Was so excited to go there too There was a guy wandering around asking the tables if everything was good but never approached us at all  not sure something to do with being the only ethnic people there. The waitress never came to ask us if we needed anything but did make sure to ask us to leave cos a big party had reserved the table. However NO ONE was waiting outside at all to get in. Thanks!!!

cfKnJjOWZ4ix_zbPhAUQoA.text: Look, it would be unfair to compare this location to the original, but the food I confidently say is comparable. Nothing about the homemade mozzarella and local tomato and basil 'caprese' salad was to fault. Follow that up with the Sonny and Margherita pies...uh, yeah...the Town and Country location are another Bianco masterpiece! The service was rapid as always, and at times lacking attentiveness, however it's never a deal breaker for me.  Felt sorry for our server who had to handle the high maintenance customers who wanted to meet the chef, said their bottle of Merlot was "corked" (not kidding). However it was quite entertaining and made our visit even much more memorable.  This location, from a foodie perspective doesn't lack anything that the Heritage Square location brings. Don't let it scare you off.  Of course if I had to pick I would always go old school original, however blindfolded if the food is the same,does it really matter? Great job as always Mr. Bianco...wine snobs and all.

ja3d2xGyDVlw_CWAJtOd-Q.text: The ambiance was nothing special.  It reminded me of someone's grandmothers house.   I told the waiter I had a food allergy to certain oil's and they assured me my salad's dressing only had olive oil in it.  Well I had a reaction so I'm sure it did contain additional oils besides olive oil.   The pizza was pretty good but for $15 we expected something a little more substantial. We were overcharged for salads on our bill.  The menu said the house green salads were $6 and we were charged $8 each.  The waitress apologized and said that we were accidently charged for dinner salads instead of lunch salads.

7GoQipa_l2Kunf0XVkrKGg.text: Horrible waitress, huge disappointment. We were in town for Spring Training and this place was recommended. It took over an hour to be seated (estimated 25 by hostess) and an addition 30 to get food. We thought 'this place must be good". Complimentary bread is served with plain olive oil - no flavor. We ordered the green salad, a side of mushrooms and two pizzas. The salad and pizzas were nothing special, not bad but not good. We had to stop someone to get the mushrooms we ordered as they were not brought, obviously forgotten. The guy who brought them apologized and did not charge them to us but they were dry and didn't have flavor. The worse part was our server. She never checked on us, wasn't apologetic about forgetting our mushrooms and we had to flag her down to get the check. Do not recommend!

Xa-_NhqG83V_H6Pr9IEuQg.text: I laugh at these weak reviews. You clearly don't know about True  Napolitano style pizza, or are not seeing or tasting the details and nuances that go into this pie. The doe is perfect with a little bit a stretch to it, the toppings are just right, not too much sauce, not too much cheese. The margherita pizza is the best in the state. Even next to Pomo this is hands down the best. Basil is fresh sauce is boss and the mozz is different but its rich as done right. The Rosa is amazing. Pistachios, rosemary, red onions, and Parmesan reggiano. Service is usually great, and the food is usually consistent. They always take care of us. Chris bianco knows what he's doing. Panne Bianco and the downtown location also do a fantastic job. If you want american pizza go somewhere else, this is gourmet connoisseur pie. And I've been to New York, ate pizza in every borough and grew up with Italians on the east coast, so take my word for it.

BlKOHWqTT4UxyD7XjL67Fw.text: Just like it's other location, this place is great. And because not everyone knows about it and they now serve lunch, there's not a wait.  (At least for me there was not). They even bring you out some warm olives to snack on as you wait for your food. I went with the Sonny Boy, and boy, it was heaven! Perfectly thin crust with delicious toppings.  My mouth is drooling thinking about it.  Next time in the valley, I will be back to try some of their other offerings.

MFgZPrnncADjtivZ7ga93w.text: LOVE that this is close to my house and that the wait was only 20 min. Love both the verde and wiseguy pizza.

-jh53ZT9pn0YskkWCaSw1g.text: We have been wanting to try this place for a while and finally made our way there tonight. Unfortunately, it wasn't quite what we expected. The appetizer of fresh mozzarella and tomatoes was great but it went downhill from there. Not only did the waiter seem annoyed and uninterested but half of our order came out wrong. When we informed the staff that one of our pizzas was supposed to have mushrooms, they just brought out a side of mushrooms instead of remaking the pizza. Very strange to me. Overall, I think we were all glad we tried it but mostly because now we know we aren't missing much.

c_mS_43pdYevU2tVC05S0Q.text: I'm happy to say this is our neighborhood Italian restaurant. This up town version of bianco is more relaxed and less trendy in my opinion. Trattoria has a totally different menu too...

6hYLsJYzw_XSYLZIgSW3bQ.text: Great natural ingredients, simple and wonderful.

7eFHMEjzOEiFn28u-AerYA.text: Pizzeria Bianco is widely acknowledged as some of the best Pizza (or The Best to some reivewers) in the nation. Not sure what I can add except to say it was terrific!  The Princess and I went to his second location in the Town and Country shopping center (Biltmore area) and walked right in at 5 PM.  The location is wonderful, setting is nice looking out onto the courtyard and it appears there are tables you can use if the weather is not 110 as it was during our visit.  We ordered a nice Italian red wine for The P and I had a negroni, both were fantastic.  The meal started with a small complimentary bowl of five small kalmata olives and  a few slices of their in-house bread with a bowl of olive oil, nice touch.  I ordered their famous wise guy and The P ordered the sonny boy. The wise guy is white sauced based with wonderful fennel sausage from Shrieners (local meat co.) fennel, roasted onions. Wood fired, the Pizza was excellent.  However, I actually enjoyed the sonny boy more.  It was red sauce based with soppresseta and it was, IMHO, one of the best pizzas I've ever had.  We finished the meal with flourless chocolate cake, very good with a vanilla sauce.  Service was delightful, server was attentive without being in our face.  Loved the small touches such as real silverware (Oneida).  Attention to detail has made Mr. Bianco a success and I'm humbled to be able to join the chorus of people who sing his and his restaurants praises!  Slainte!

dnzyiL1PPX08sSag_Gppjg.text: Subdued, comfortable dining room, arrogant servers and mediocre pasta. Yep. I said it! Started the meal with stale bread a 20 min wait for beverages. The olive oil was tasty but I'm assuming the guys in the back had nothing to do with that. Mind you it was 5pm on a Wednesday. When our server did bring drinks I mentioned this was our first time and we looked forward to some authentic pasta. He stared into my eyes, awkwardly, and said, "Yep, were kind of the real deal". I knew then we were in for it. The pizza was fine but the pappardelle with bolognese was umm.. Not amazing. It wasn't the pasta itself rather the sauce that turned me off. Bland, slightly tomatoey and vaguely creamy with a smattering of coarsely ground meat. Just not what I know Bolognese to be. In my world it's deep red and heavy on pancetta, ground veal or pork and beef with just enough tomato to make everything come together. They missed the target. Sorry guys. If you want a decent pizza give it a shot or just find a Grimaldi's, La Bocca or Isa's. Have I been harsh? Maybe, but I'm tired of these trendy spots telling me what the "Real Deal" is. Thanks but no thanks. Next time I want good pasta I'm staying home.

VY0jp57cwrUs5N49FD95Xg.text: I have rated over 100 places on yelp and have yet to want to give a place NEGATIVE stars if I could...until I stumbled upon this dump. I couldn't WAIT to get home to write this review.  Not only was the food nasty the service was horrible, and the manager, Tyler should be ashamed of himself. Whoever hired Tyler needs a camera in his restaurant to see his demeanor towards guests. A group of 25 of us made dinner reservations here to celebrate our friend's birthday. I ordered the mozzarella as an appetizer and the chicken ranch as my entree. The mozzarella (home made) was nothing special. The chicken was battered and deep fried-but actually burned.  I couldn't eat it so i asked for a side of marinara-hoping it would taste better. Wow the marinara was the most disgusting sauce I had ever had.  Canned tomato sauce tastes better.   By the way they charge you $3 for that crap. Everyone hated their food.  Furthermore, they wouldn't split the check more than 6 ways. They wouldn't allow us to bring our cake out. The manager came out upon our request, we asked him where the nearest ATM was and he had the nerve to roll his eyes at us. He was so unbelievably rude. I was astonished. He refused to split the check further and was basically yelling at us.  He should be fired. I wish there was more I could do about this. He ruined our dinner. The service was also lacking. None of the food came out together at one time.  DON'T COME HERE. You get better pizza at Papa John's or Dominoes for a quarter of the price. I promise.  BEWARE

WnHxw37BhOFT58Xbba87Pg.text: Ok I know the pizza is the thing at Bianco's restaurants but tonight in addition we had the gnocchi in brown butter and sage sauce and seriously it was one of the best things I've ever eaten!  They were light, browned and buttery. Exquisite!  The Tres Leche cake was also excellent. Can't wait for the new restaurant to open!

k-gjiz2thWhoAoT7epe2cg.text: Was recommended to come here because it's suppose to be one of the best pizza joints in PHX. Came here- cool atmosphere and it was nice to sit outside. Ordered the "wise guy" pizza and to be honest...it was ok. I didn't realize it didn't have sauce, so I ordered some marinara on the side. Pizza was better after that but still overall, it was just an ok pizza to me. The crust was a bit burnt too, which I didn't really like. Only gave it 3 stars b/c for the type of pizza, didn't think it was worth the price. Feel like I could get the same "meh" slice for half the money elsewhere.

z90G2ISkfsLnGcFp_GCS2g.text: Hard to believe this is a Chris Bianco restaurant, at least tonight. I ate here a month ago and loved it and was so excited to come back tonight with friends for a belated birthday celebration. I am writing this from the parking lot -- that's how bad an experience it was.    The sausage pasta dish was nothing like the last time, when it was the hit of the night. . The texture was like paste. We sent it back and when the server returned with a new order she said: chef wants you to know we are experimenting with different wheats and it's all matter of personal taste and palates. In other words, if you don't like it you don't have good taste. We chewed through the toughness -again - because we were so hungry. The only good part was the sausage.   Service was a comedy of errors. We got our neighbors' appetizers, much to their dismay.    It's 114 today and was over 90 degrees in the restaurant. The hostess just said she "thought" the AC was out. The people next to us were fanning themselves with their menu. Other people moved tables to try to get cooler but the hostess told us we had one of the best spots in the house.     Our waitress made no attempt to apologize for any of this mess and dropped the check off with no comment or even the slightest bit of recognition -or discount /free meal - for the troubles. Not even an acknowledgement that this place was firing on NO cylinders tonight.  Absolutely stunning. It was like the whole place was in an alternate universe where everything was peachy keen tonight. There were some high Profile PHX area biz and foodie  diners there tonight whom I will not mention. We can only imagine what they thought, or maybe the kitchen was lavishing all of their attention on them.    I was embarrassed I suggested it for my birthday dinner with friends.

GI5spdMlQ4QGCu65sN_ICA.text: So here's the thing, this place was amazing. Amazing food, great service and at an excellent location. However, they charged me $145.00 for a $45.00 bill so definitely going to need someone to contact me for a credit. Hopefully they read this because they don't answer their phone.

kNRdxWtR1Tf5ZpGqjc7QlA.text: This place is too loud.  It would have been nice to have a meal without some lady yelling 'meatlog' across the room.  Also the waitstaff was somewhat incompetent and snobby.  The food was delicious but it's not something anyone can make themselves at home.  They are stingy with their bread even though it is now free. Lots of annoying things that will probably persuade me not to come back.

j7GWsoRKBMlWJdqWhYIQFQ.text: The best pizza I have ever had, in the nine years of my life. After we ate we watched them making the wonderful, tasty food and the manager came out to take a picture  with our girls. He also said next time he would let them walk through the kitchen and meet everyone.

Lvf85aQnMbLF2VkxV0N03g.text: first time visit so called ahead and when the gal said the reservations were booked for Sunday @6 but  they leave plenty for walkins, we left to head over with a short drive.  we parked over by Nordstrom Rack, walked thru to the center, and got our table immediately with great service the whole time.  for the four of us, we ordered the Brussels sprout salad and two different pizzas and with bread that was a good amount for the group.  the Brussels sprout salad was tasty and healthy but the pizzas were fab! each for $18 for a not large pizza.  we got the wise guy with delicious spicy fennel sausage and the bianco verde add mushrooms.  the parm and ricotta had such good flavor paired with the arugla - we devoured  them both!  the crust is thin and crispy and especially yum, not drenched in pizza sauce.  so glad this location is here - the manager was very generous with a little snafu that happened and we appreciated the customer service without even asking!  very cute candlelight decor in the lovely dining room but just a little dim.  next time we would try another pizza and maybe a pasta.  we really enjoyed it and will be back!

I wish I could take this restaurant back to Seattle with me.

5rSaA1oVPMeS2vTWZwxmxg.text: Great pizza! Not the best in town but great. Service was slow in the beginning but picked up when we got our food. Also, loved that they serve local brews!

x4YYrd8kgEy-gNPJ9uRucw.text: I'm a New Haven guy and i consider myself a pizza aficionado. My last meal choice would be Sally's Pizza in New Haven if i had a day to live (who knows). I've read about Pizzeria Bianco for years. It always shows up on the top ten pizzeria in the US lists. I was surprised that we didn't need reservations and we walked right in. The manager , Dave, was gregarious and gracious. The pizza was really good, I'd say that it was really delicious. Sally's, it's not but their Neapolitan style is thin crispy and topped with quality clean ingredients. Next time in PHX, I'd def stop in again.  I almost forgot, Kelly, our beer-tender and server was attentive and quick. Nice job Kelly.

The sonny boy pizza wasn't as good as it tasted more Greek than anything with the olives and couldn't taste the sauce. ZdyhrBc8ySZq8Sg_PyDXmg.text: Tasty! Good pizza, relaxing atmosphere, and very friendly staff. I would recommend stopping by here and trying their food.

Ezcg4fIvkKlX6HrVvx06ZA.text: Awesome little find in the middle of a quiet shopping district. We found it a lovely place to escape amidst the weekend bustle of shopping and errands. As soon as you step through the doors you're met with a homey and Victorian style dining room that whisks you into what feels like a relaxing Italian getaway. Each detail from the waiters in long aprons, mismatched wood furniture and water served from glass bottles contribute to the beautiful and thoughtful authentic-family-run feel - despite the location sandwiched behind a Trader Joe's and surrounds shops. Although we weren't able to indulge during our visit, the wine list offered a thorough selection and the food we did try was scrumptious - giving pizza the respect it deserves. Although nothing from the dessert menu particularly caught our eye, this seems like the perfect place to step in and stay for a while for a romantic lunch date or to savor some classy pizza and wine.

G-PQlPHR8De5VFiFGBN_3w.text: The ingredients are so fresh! The pizza is delicious, but is it worth the price I'm on the edge on that. I feel like I have had better pizza at better price butttt still delicious. The dough is so perfectly cooked.  The services are quick and sincere. Atmosphere is very relaxing and comfortable. Highly recommend it here for date night!

WrBm3RVfzw0vm6xOdH2EuQ.text: I love their food. I didn't realize they had a 2nd location until yesterday. I went there for lunch and had a great salad and pizza. Their pizza is thin and crispy just how I like it. They also have a nice little patio to sit outside. I'll be back.
